cmCourseInfo.description: Geologic hazards: earthquakes, volcanoes, landslides, tsunamis. The distribution and politics of natural resources, including petroleum and ore deposits. Nuclear power and nuclear waste disposal. Global change: the geologic record of hot and cold climates, and how the earth survives. ESS103H1 is primarily intended as a science Distribution Requirement course for Humanities and Social Science, it will be taught in odd years.
cmCourseInfo.title: Geology in Public Issues

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Meeting sections do not require attendance at a specific time or location for any activities or exams.

Delivery Instructions

The course will be offered in an asynchronous format. Lecture material will be recorded, and students will be placed in small discussion groups of 5 or 6 students each. These teams will individually decide whether they want to meet synchronously (for example via MS-Teams) or discuss course material asynchronously (for example via a discussion board). Possible online synchronous sessions, like optional tutorial meetings, will not be recorded and only be available at their scheduled times.

Students will be expected to review online material before meeting with their teams.

Students will not necessarily need video or microphone to participate in team discussions or optional tutorials, although a microphone can make interaction easier. To participate in possible online synchronous tutorials it will be necessary to have a stable internet connection and use the chat function of the platform (Zoom or MS-Teams).

cmCourseInfo.description: The evolution of ideas about the origin and development of the earth from the Athenians to the 20th Century, with attention on the age of earth; on the evolution and disappearance of species; on the origin of oceans, continents and mountains; on climate change; and on the courage of scientists in confronting the religious and political views of their time. ESS104H1 is primarily intended as a science Distribution Requirement course for Humanities and Social Science students. Taught in even years.
cmCourseInfo.title: Controversies in Earth Science

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: The nature and evolution of the Earth; plate tectonics; rocks and minerals; volcanism; geological time; fossils; geology of Ontario; environmental issues; and human interactions with the planet. ESS105H1 is primarily intended as a science Distribution Requirement course for Humanities and Social Science students
cmCourseInfo.title: Our home planet

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: The emergence of society as a major geological force is considered in terms of the evolving debate about the consequences of human activity for the habitability of our planet. Major issues such as climate change, environmental pollution, and depletion of natural resources are examined.
cmCourseInfo.title: Confronting Global Change

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

cmCourseInfo.description: A two-week field course in early May or late August. Students are introduced to field geology and to basic field measurement, mapping and documentation techniques (for example in the Espanola - Manitoulin Island area, west of Sudbury). Students are responsible for the cost of board and lodging and transport to and from the field area. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Note: Enrollment is handled by the department. For registration deadlines, additional fees associated with the field course, course dates, and special registration requirements, please consult the departmental announcements or inquire with ugrad@es.utoronto.ca.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Geological Field Methods

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: Credit course for supervised participation in faculty research project. Details at https://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/academics/research-opportunities/research-opportunities-program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Opportunity Program

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

nrolment for the Research Opportunity Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/focus/course/rop

cmCourseInfo.description: A two-week advanced geological mapping project in a challenging field environment. Students learn to compile existing geoscience data, create a geological map and prepare a professional final report on their activities and findings. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. For registration deadlines, additional fees associated with the field course, course dates, and special registration requirements, please consult the departmental announcements or inquire with ugrad@es.utoronto.ca.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Geological Field Methods

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: An individual study program chosen by the student with the advice, and under the supervision, of a faculty member. Such work may involve obtaining data in the field or lab and analysing it, an interdisciplinary research project, and supervised readings. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Directed Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: enrollment in an Earth Science program of study, completion of at least one full-course equivalent of 200-series ESS courses.

Timetable Instructions

To enrol in this course, please contact Scott Moore, the Undergraduate Administrator, at s.moore@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description:
"

A ten-day field course in late summer at the Deep River field site designed to familiarize students in a variety of hydrogeological and biogeochemical field techniques; includes a mixture of lecture, laboratory and field exercises. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Note: Enrollment is handled by the department. For registration deadlines, additional fees associated with the field course, course dates, and special registration requirements, please consult the departmental announcements or inquire with ugrad@es.utoronto.ca. Additional fee of up to $500 will apply.

"
cmCourseInfo.title: Field Techniques in Hydrogeochemistry

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: A ten-day field course in late August at the Deep River field site. Students get hands-on experience using geophysical instrumentation, applying various data collection techniques, and performing data analysis in gravity, magnetic, seismic, electrical, electromagnetic, and radar surveys. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Note: Enrollment is handled by the department. For registration deadlines, additional fees associated with the field course, course dates, and special registration requirements, please consult the departmental announcements or inquire with ugrad@es.utoronto.ca. Additional fee of up to $500 will apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Geophysical Field Techniques

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description:
"

A two-week excursion to a challenging field setting. Students will integrate field observations with their accumulated knowledge of geodynamics, structural geology, and landscape evolution to understand large-scale geological events. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. This course can be offered in any given term. Note: Enrolment is handled by the department. For registration deadlines, additional fees associated with the field course, course dates, and special registration requirements, please consult the departmental announcements or inquire with ugrad@es.utoronto.ca. Additional fee of up to $900 may apply.

"
cmCourseInfo.title: Geological Capstone Fieldtrip
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 12.0 credits from any Earth Science program of study requirements. Students who do not meet the prerequisite are encouraged to contact the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: ESS221H1/ESS224H1, ESS262H1, ESS222H1, ESS234H1, ESS331H1, ESS423H1
